title: NIOS Class 12 Physics - April 2025 Comprehensive MCQs
subtitle: Expanded practice set derived from the April 2025 question paper (Code 69/MAY/4 - Sets u, v, w)

questions.question: In Young's double-slit setup using 6000 Å light, 99 fringes occupy a given region. How many fringes will appear in the same region with 5500 Å light?
questions.explanation: Fringe count is inversely proportional to wavelength, so N' = 99 * 6000 / 5500 is approximately 108 fringes.

questions.question: Which logic gate is known as a universal gate because it can be used to implement any Boolean function?
questions.explanation: The NAND gate alone can be combined to realise all fundamental logic operations, making it a universal gate.

questions.question: A solid cylinder of density half that of water floats upright in water with half its volume immersed. If it floats in oil with one-fifth of its volume above the surface, what is the relative density of the oil?
questions.explanation: Weight balance in oil gives ρ_object/ρ_oil = immersed fraction = 4/5. With ρ_object = 0.5 ρ_water, the oil density is (0.5)/(4/5) = 5/8 relative to water.

questions.question: A travelling wave on a string is represented by y(x, t) = A sin(kx - ωt). What is the maximum transverse speed of any particle of the string?
questions.explanation: Differentiating y with respect to time gives v_y = Aω cos(kx - ωt), whose magnitude is maximised at Aω.

questions.question: Two point charges q1 and q2 exert a force F at separation r. If each charge is halved and the separation is also halved, what is the new force between them?
questions.explanation: Coulomb's law gives F' = k(q1/2)(q2/2)/(r/2)^2 = kq1q2/r^2 = F.

questions.question: What is the dimensional formula of electric field intensity?
questions.explanation: Electric field E has units of force per unit charge: (MLT−2)/(AT) = MLT−3A−1.

questions.question: A charged parallel-plate capacitor is disconnected from the battery and the plate separation is increased. What happens to the potential difference between the plates?
questions.explanation: Charge remains constant; capacitance falls as d increases, so V = Q/C grows.

questions.question: Which factor does not influence the capacitance of a parallel-plate capacitor?
questions.explanation: Capacitance depends only on geometry and dielectric; charge adjusts according to C and applied voltage.

questions.question: The most accurate device for measuring the emf of a primary cell is the:
questions.explanation: A potentiometer null measurement avoids drawing current, yielding precise emf values.

questions.question: If n identical resistors each of resistance R are connected (i) in series and (ii) in parallel, what is the ratio R_s/R_p of the equivalent resistances?
questions.explanation: Series gives nR, parallel yields R/n, so their ratio is (nR)/(R/n) = n^2.

questions.question: A convex lens forms a coloured image of a white object. Which colour focuses closest to the optical centre?
questions.explanation: Violet light has the shortest focal length in glass and therefore focuses nearest to the lens.

questions.question: Prisms made of different optical glasses are identical in geometry. Which produces the widest visible spectrum?
questions.explanation: Flint glass has the highest dispersive power among the listed materials.

questions.question: Which property of light remains unchanged when it travels from one medium to another of different optical density?
questions.explanation: Frequency is determined by the source and is invariant across media transitions.

questions.question: When unpolarised light is incident on a polarising surface at Brewster's angle, what is the angle between the reflected and refracted rays?
questions.explanation: Brewster's law states that the reflected and refracted rays are perpendicular, i.e., separated by 90°.

questions.question: Ocean waves with crest separation 100 m travel at 25 m s−1. At what interval does a boat at anchor rise to successive crests?
questions.explanation: Wave speed v = λ/T gives T = λ/v = 100/25 = 4 s between crests.

questions.question: Two coherent sources have intensities in the ratio 9 : 1. What is the ratio of maximum to minimum intensity in their interference pattern?
Which law of thermodynamics forbids the complete conversion of heat into work in a cyclic process?
questions.explanation: The Kelvin-Planck statement of the second law prohibits 100% conversion of heat into work.

questions.question: Which form of energy is most fundamentally linked to the thermal motion of particles in matter?
questions.explanation: Thermal energy corresponds to the random kinetic energy of microscopic constituents.

questions.question: Which electromagnetic radiation has wavelengths shorter than those of X-rays?
questions.explanation: Gamma rays occupy the shorter-wavelength, higher-frequency end beyond X-rays.

questions.question: Infrared radiations are popularly known as:
questions.explanation: Infrared radiation is sensed as heat, hence the term heat waves.

questions.question: Which incident particle most effectively initiates a nuclear reaction because it carries no charge?
questions.explanation: Neutrons, lacking electric charge, readily penetrate nuclei and trigger reactions.

questions.question: For sustaining a chain fission reaction in ²³⁵U, neutrons must typically have kinetic energy:
questions.explanation: Thermal (slow) neutrons with energies below 0.1 eV are most effective in inducing fission in ²³⁵U.

questions.question: In a stationary wave, what is the separation between two consecutive nodes?
questions.explanation: Nodes (or antinodes) in a standing wave are spaced half a wavelength apart.

questions.question: SONAR systems for underwater ranging employ which type of waves?
questions.explanation: SONAR uses high-frequency ultrasonic waves that reflect effectively underwater.

questions.question: Two coherent waves have intensities in the ratio 1 : 4. What is the ratio of maximum to minimum intensity in the interference fringes?
As you move away from an isolated negative point charge, how does the electric potential change?
options: It decreases non-linearly toward negative infinity
questions.explanation: V = -kq/r becomes less negative (approaches zero) as r grows, so it increases non-linearly.

questions.question: For the wave y(x, t) = A sin(kx - ωt), what is the phase velocity of propagation along the string?
questions.explanation: Comparing with sin(kx - ωt) gives v = ω/k for a travelling wave.

questions.question: Two point charges q1 and q2 separated by r exert force F. If both charges are doubled and the distance is halved, what is the new force?
n identical cells each of emf E and internal resistance r are connected in parallel. What are the equivalent emf and internal resistance of the battery?
questions.explanation: Parallel identical sources maintain the same emf E while the internal resistance reduces to r/n.

questions.question: A convex lens forms coloured images of white light. Which colour focuses farthest from the optical centre on the axis?
questions.explanation: Red light has the longest focal length in glass, so its image plane is farthest from the lens.

questions.question: Two coherent sources produce waves with amplitude ratio 3 : 5. What is the ratio of maximum to minimum intensity in the interference pattern?
Which logic gate outputs LOW only when all its inputs are HIGH?
questions.explanation: A NAND gate gives 0 output solely for the case when every input is 1.

questions.question: What is the frequency of oscillation of a standing wave if successive nodes are 0.15 m apart and the wave speed is 180 m s−1?
questions.explanation: Node spacing equals λ/2, so λ = 0.3 m and f = v/λ = 180/0.3 = 600 Hz.

questions.question: A galvanometer is converted into a voltmeter by connecting a high resistance in series. This arrangement keeps which quantity essentially constant?
questions.explanation: The series multiplier limits current to the galvanometer's small full-scale value regardless of applied voltage.

questions.question: Which method best reduces rolling friction between a wheel and an axle?
questions.explanation: Lubricants create a low-shear film that minimises solid-to-solid contact and friction.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of conservation of linear momentum?
options: A rotating fan slows due to air resistance
A gun recoils when firing a bullet
An electron spirals in a magnetic field
A block sliding to rest on a rough floor
questions.explanation: Gun and bullet form an isolated system exchanging equal and opposite momenta, illustrating momentum conservation.

questions.question: Which diode is specifically designed to operate in reverse bias near its breakdown region for voltage regulation?
questions.explanation: Zener diodes exploit avalanche or Zener breakdown in reverse bias to maintain nearly constant voltage.

questions.question: In a p-n junction diode, which side (p or n) is typically marked to identify the anode lead?
options: The p-side with a longer lead
The n-side with a red band
The p-side with a silver band
The n-side with a shorter lead
questions.explanation: Manufacturers usually leave the p-region (anode) lead longer, while the n-side (cathode) often has a band marking.

questions.question: Identifying the p and n regions of a diode is necessary primarily to:
options: Ensure correct biasing in a circuit
questions.explanation: Proper circuit connection requires knowing which terminal will be forward- or reverse-biased.

questions.question: A book rests on a table. Which pair of forces represents the action-reaction pair according to Newton's third law?
options: Weight of the book and normal on the book
Normal on the book and normal on the table
Normal on the book and force exerted by the book on the table
Weight of the book and weight of the table
questions.explanation: The table pushes the book up; simultaneously the book pushes the table down with equal magnitude and opposite direction.

questions.question: A boy throws a ball of mass m vertically upward with speed v and catches it when it returns with the same speed. What is the change in momentum of the ball?
questions.explanation: Momentum reverses direction from +mv to -mv, so Δp = -mv - (+mv) = -2mv; magnitude is 2mv downward.

questions.question: What is Reynolds number used for in fluid mechanics?
options: Predicting the type of flow (laminar or turbulent)
questions.explanation: Reynolds number Re = ρvD/η distinguishes laminar (low Re) from turbulent (high Re) flow regimes.

questions.question: Which combination of variables appears in the Reynolds number for flow in a pipe of diameter D?
questions.explanation: Re = (density)(velocity)(diameter)/(dynamic viscosity).

questions.question: Terminal velocity of a small sphere falling through a viscous fluid is defined as the speed at which:
options: Net force on the sphere becomes zero
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, weight equals the sum of drag and buoyancy, giving zero net force and thus constant speed.

questions.question: Which expression gives the terminal velocity v_t of a sphere of radius r and density ρ_s falling in a fluid of viscosity η and density ρ_f?
questions.explanation: Using Stokes' law, v_t = 2r^2(ρ_s - ρ_f)g/(9η).

questions.question: List the correct sequence of strokes in an ideal Carnot cycle starting from the isothermal expansion stage.
options: Isothermal expansion → adiabatic expansion → isothermal compression → adiabatic compression
Isothermal expansion → adiabatic compression → isothermal compression → adiabatic expansion
Adiabatic expansion → isothermal expansion → adiabatic compression → isothermal compression
Isothermal compression → adiabatic expansion → isothermal expansion → adiabatic compression
questions.explanation: The Carnot cycle consists of two isothermal and two adiabatic processes arranged in the stated order.

questions.question: What is the Boolean expression for the output of a NOT gate?
questions.explanation: A NOT gate simply outputs the logical complement: Y = A'.

questions.question: Consider the truth table of a NOT gate. What is the output when the input is logic 1?
questions.explanation: NOT gate inverts its input, so an input of 1 yields an output of 0.

questions.question: A 2 kg block rests on a horizontal surface with coefficient of static friction 0.3. What is the limiting friction force (take g = 10 m s−2)?
What is the momentum of a photon with frequency ν?
questions.explanation: Photon momentum p = hν/c = h/λ.

questions.question: Which component is used along with a transformer and rectifier to obtain a stabilized DC supply?
questions.explanation: A capacitor filter smooths pulsating DC before a regulator such as a Zener diode maintains a steady output.

questions.question: Which spectral lines are explained by the Raman effect?
questions.explanation: Raman spectra arise from inelastic scattering, producing Stokes and anti-Stokes shifted lines.

questions.question: In Raman scattering, Stokes lines correspond to:
questions.explanation: Stokes lines appear at lower frequencies because scattered photons lose energy, exciting molecular vibrations.

questions.question: An anti-Stokes line in a Raman spectrum indicates that the scattered photon has:
questions.explanation: Anti-Stokes scattering occurs when the molecule is initially excited and transfers energy to the photon, raising its frequency.

questions.question: Calculate the work done when a force ⇒F = 5Ĥi + 3Ĥj N causes a displacement ⇒d = 3Ĥi + 4Ĥj m.
The characteristics of a forward-biased p-n junction diode are obtained using which typical circuit element in series?
questions.explanation: A current-limiting resistor protects the diode while plotting its I-V curve.

questions.question: In reverse bias, the I-V characteristic of a diode shows a sharp rise at breakdown. This region is used in which application?
questions.explanation: Zener diodes exploit the sudden current rise in breakdown to stabilise voltage across a load.

questions.question: Water flows steadily through a horizontal pipe narrowing from area A1 to A2. If the speed at section 1 is v1, what is the speed at section 2 (neglect viscosity)?
questions.explanation: Continuity for incompressible flow gives v2 = v1A1/A2.

questions.question: In Bernoulli's equation for incompressible steady flow, the sum of pressure head, velocity head, and elevation head is:
questions.explanation: Bernoulli's theorem states p/ρg + v^2/2g + z = constant along a streamline.

questions.question: If water flows in a horizontal pipe such that its speed increases from 0.2 m s−1 to 1.5 m s−1, how does the pressure change according to Bernoulli's principle?
questions.explanation: Higher speed in the constriction means lower static pressure to conserve total energy per unit volume.

questions.question: A capillary tube of radius r is dipped vertically into water (surface tension T, contact angle theta approximately 0). The rise h is proportional to:
questions.explanation: The Jurin's law gives h = 2Tcosθ/(ρgr), inversely proportional to tube radius.

questions.question: A liquid of density 1000 kg m−3 rises 6.0 cm in a capillary of radius 0.2 mm. Taking g = 10 m s−2, what is the surface tension?
The Raman spectrum of a substance shows a strong line shifted to lower frequency relative to the incident light. This indicates:
options: Energy transfer from photon to molecule
questions.explanation: Lower frequency (Stokes) scattering signifies that the photon lost energy exciting vibrational modes.

questions.question: What is the main reason the central maximum in Young's double-slit experiment is brightest?
options: Path difference is half a wavelength
Two coherent waves interfere constructively with equal amplitude
Screen is closest at the centre
questions.explanation: At the central bright fringe the path difference is zero, so amplitudes add maximally.

questions.question: If the slit separation in Young's experiment is tripled while keeping other parameters constant, the fringe width becomes:
questions.explanation: Fringe width β = λD/d is inversely proportional to slit separation d.

questions.question: In Young's double-slit setup using 6000 Å light, 99 fringes occupy a given region. How many fringes will appear in the same region with 5500 Å light?
questions.explanation: Number of fringes ∝ 1/λ, so N' = N(λ/λ') = 99 × 6000/5500 ≈ 108? Wait that's 108?", but we predicted 108? let's recalc. 6000/5500 = 1.0909; 99 * 6000/5500 ≈ 108.0. So correct 108. Need to adjust options: We'll set correct option to 108. We'll adjust options accordingly.

questions.question: What is the Balmer series expression for the wavenumber of hydrogen spectral lines?
questions.explanation: Balmer series corresponds to electron transitions ending at n = 2.

questions.question: Paschen series of hydrogen lies in which region of the electromagnetic spectrum?
questions.explanation: Paschen transitions terminate at n = 3 and produce infrared wavelengths.

questions.question: The wavenumber expression for Paschen series is:
questions.explanation: Paschen lines correspond to transitions ending at principal quantum number n = 3.

questions.question: Superposition of two coherent light waves always produces a central maximum that is:
options: Twice as wide as other maxima
Half the width of other maxima
questions.explanation: In standard Young's pattern all bright fringes, including the central one, have equal width determined by β.

questions.question: Huygens' wave theory explains reflection and refraction in terms of:
options: Secondary wavelets forming a new wavefront
questions.explanation: Huygens proposed that every point on a wavefront acts as a source of secondary wavelets whose envelope yields the propagated wavefront.

questions.question: Radioactive decay rates depend primarily on:
questions.explanation: Decay constant is characteristic of the isotope and is unaffected by normal environmental conditions.

questions.question: Can the decay rate of a radioactive element be significantly increased by raising its temperature to a few hundred degrees Celsius?
questions.explanation: Radioactive decay is a nuclear process independent of ordinary thermal effects.

questions.question: Is it theoretically feasible to transmute iron into gold using artificial radioactivity techniques?
options: Yes, but it is impractical and uneconomical
No, because gold nuclei do not exist
questions.explanation: Nuclear reactions could produce gold from iron but the process is massively energy-intensive and economically infeasible.

questions.question: What is the upper fixed point on Kelvin's thermodynamic temperature scale?
questions.explanation: The Kelvin scale is defined using the triple point of water as the fundamental fixed point (273.16 K).

questions.question: An ideal heat engine operating between ice point and steam point has maximum theoretical efficiency of approximately:
questions.explanation: Efficiency = (T_hot - T_cold)/T_hot = (373 - 273)/373 ≈ 26.9%.

questions.question: Young's double-slit experiment uses slit separation d. If d is tripled, the fringe width becomes what fraction of its original value?
questions.explanation: Fringe width β ∝ 1/d, so tripling d reduces β to one-third.

questions.question: When the wavelength of light in Young's setup changes from 6000 Å to 5500 Å, the number of fringes in a fixed span becomes:
Which phenomenon is responsible for the formation of a rainbow when sunlight passes through raindrops?
questions.explanation: Rainbow formation relies on wavelength-dependent refraction and internal reflection, i.e., dispersion.

questions.question: The blue colour of the sky is primarily due to:
questions.explanation: Short-wavelength light is scattered more efficiently by air molecules, giving the sky its blue hue.

questions.question: In a heated metal, which electrons are responsible for thermal emission of electrons?
questions.explanation: Thermionic emission arises from conduction electrons gaining enough energy to escape the work function barrier.

questions.question: A metal has a threshold frequency of 1.160 × 10^15 Hz. What is its work function in electron volts (h = 6.626 × 10^-34 J s, 1 eV = 1.6 × 10^-19 J)?
Will photoemission occur from the metal in Question 82 if incident light has frequency 1.20 × 10^15 Hz?
options: No, because frequency is below threshold
questions.explanation: Any frequency above the threshold (1.160×10^15 Hz) can eject electrons regardless of intensity.

questions.question: What is the stopping potential if light of frequency 1.20 × 10^15 Hz falls on the metal of work function 4.8 eV?
questions.explanation: Photon energy equals 4.96 eV and subtracting the 4.8 eV work function leaves 0.16 eV, so the stopping potential is 0.16 V.

questions.question: Which semiconductor material is most commonly used in LED fabrication for red emission?
questions.explanation: GaAsP alloys allow direct bandgap transitions producing red to orange light in LEDs.

questions.question: In an n-type semiconductor, the majority charge carriers are:
questions.explanation: Donor doping introduces excess conduction-band electrons as majority carriers.

questions.question: Which impurity creates a p-type semiconductor when added to silicon?
questions.explanation: Trivalent boron accepts electrons, generating holes as majority carriers.

questions.question: A silicon diode has a forward voltage drop of about 0.7 V. At the same current level, a germanium diode would drop approximately:
questions.explanation: Germanium diodes typically show about 0.3 V forward drop due to smaller bandgap.

questions.question: In a common-emitter amplifier, the input is applied between which terminals?
questions.explanation: The input signal drives the base-emitter junction in the CE configuration.

questions.question: Current gain (β) in a common-emitter BJT is defined as the ratio of:
questions.explanation: β = I_C/I_B for a CE transistor.

questions.question: Voltage gain of a transistor amplifier is given by:
questions.explanation: Voltage gain A_v = V_out/V_in by definition.

questions.question: In a stabilized power supply, a Zener diode is normally connected:
questions.explanation: The Zener diode shunts the load to maintain a constant voltage across it.

questions.question: Which term best describes the process of removing the AC component after rectification?
questions.explanation: A filter (often a capacitor) smooths the pulsating DC output of a rectifier.

questions.question: In a half-wave rectifier, the ripple factor is approximately:
questions.explanation: Ripple factor r = 1.21 for a half-wave rectifier without filtering.

questions.question: A transformer used in a rectifier power supply steps down 230 V AC to 12 V AC. What is the turns ratio N_primary:N_secondary?
questions.explanation: Turns ratio = V_primary/V_secondary = 230/12 ≈ 19.2.

questions.question: What is the magnetic effect responsible for the force between two parallel current-carrying conductors?
questions.explanation: Each conductor generates a magnetic field that exerts a Lorentz force on the current in the other wire.

questions.question: Two long parallel wires carry equal currents in the same direction. The force between them is:
questions.explanation: Like currents attract due to the direction of magnetic fields produced around the wires.

questions.question: Two straight parallel wires 5 m long are 0.30 m apart and carry currents 10 A and 15 A in the same direction. What is the magnitude of the force between them? (μ0/4π = 10^-7 N A^-2)
Does the force in Question 98 tend to increase or decrease the separation between the wires?
questions.explanation: Attractive force pulls the wires toward each other, reducing separation.

questions.question: Why do two infinitely long parallel conductors carrying currents interact at all?
options: Each produces a magnetic field affecting the other
questions.explanation: The magnetic field created by one conductor exerts a Lorentz force on charges moving in the other conductor.

questions.question: How is a galvanometer converted into an ammeter of 0-2 A range if its full-scale current is 2.5 mA and coil resistance 12 ohm?
questions.explanation: The required shunt is R_s = I_g R_g/(I - I_g) = 0.0025 * 12/(2 - 0.0025) ≈ 0.015 ohm.

questions.question: To convert the same galvanometer into a 0-10 V voltmeter, which series resistance is required?
questions.explanation: Multiplier resistance R = (V/I_g) - R_g = (10/0.0025) - 12 = 3988 ohm, i.e. 3.988 kOhm.

questions.question: Work is defined as the product of:
options: Force and displacement in any direction
Force and displacement in the direction of force
questions.explanation: Work done W = ⇒F ⋅ ⇒s equals the component of force along displacement times the displacement magnitude.

questions.question: Energy is best described as:
questions.explanation: Energy quantifies a system's ability to perform work.

questions.question: Power is defined as:
questions.explanation: Power P = dW/dt.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of work?
questions.explanation: Work is measured in joules (N m).

questions.question: Which of the following events involves a force acting yet no mechanical work done on the body?
options: A satellite moving in a circular orbit
A car accelerating on a straight road
A block sliding down a rough incline
questions.explanation: Gravitational force on a satellite is perpendicular to its velocity, so no work is done.

questions.question: Another example where force acts but work done is zero is:
options: A crate pushed across a floor
A person carrying a load at constant height
questions.explanation: During horizontal carrying, the applied upward force is perpendicular to horizontal displacement, so work is zero.

questions.question: Which of the following is a variable force example suitable for integration to find work?
questions.explanation: Hooke's law force F = -kx varies with extension, requiring integration to evaluate work.

questions.question: The work done by a spring force when stretched from x = 0 to x = a is:
questions.explanation: W = ∫_0^a (-kx) dx = -½ka^2.

questions.question: Which electromagnetic interaction explains why a moving charge experiences a force near a current-carrying conductor?
questions.explanation: Magnetic Lorentz force F = q(⇒v × ⇒B) acts on moving charges in the magnetic field of the conductor.

questions.question: Complete the expression for the force per unit length between parallel currents I1 and I2 separated by distance d: F/L = ?
questions.explanation: Ampere's force law gives F/L = μ0 I1 I2 /(2πd).

questions.question: The SI unit of power is:
questions.explanation: Power is measured in watts (J s−1).

questions.question: Which statement about energy is correct?
options: Energy can be created from nothing
Total energy of an isolated system remains constant
Energy is always conserved only in mechanical processes
questions.explanation: Conservation of energy holds universally for isolated systems.

questions.question: A 5 kg block on a horizontal surface has coefficient of friction 0.1. What horizontal force just starts motion?
Which of the following reduces friction by converting sliding friction into rolling friction?
questions.explanation: Ball bearings replace sliding contact with rolling contact, drastically lowering resistance.

questions.question: Which situation exemplifies conservation of linear momentum in two dimensions?
options: A ball hitting and sticking to a wall
questions.explanation: As skaters push away, their momenta are equal and opposite, conserving total momentum.

questions.question: What happens to the capacitance when a dielectric slab with κ > 1 fully fills a capacitor?
questions.explanation: Capacitance C = κε_0A/d increases in proportion to the dielectric constant.

questions.question: Which of the following quantities is not dimensionless?
questions.explanation: Electric potential has units (J C−1); the others are pure numbers.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of electric potential?
questions.explanation: Electric potential difference is measured in volts.

questions.question: The force between two charges is 20 N when separated by 5 cm. If the medium is replaced by one with relative permittivity 4, the force becomes:
questions.explanation: Electrostatic force is inversely proportional to dielectric constant: F' = F/κ = 20/4 = 5 N.

questions.question: Which method is best suited for minimising viscous drag on an aircraft wing?
questions.explanation: Streamlined profiles reduce turbulent wake and drag.

questions.question: A travelling wave y = 0.01 sin(100x - 200t) (SI units). What is its angular frequency?
questions.explanation: In y = A sin(kx - ωt), the coefficient of t is ω = 200 rad s−1.

questions.question: For the wave in Question 123, what is the wavelength?
What is the time period T for the wave of Question 123?
The wavelength of light in vacuum is 600 nm. In a medium with refractive index 1.5, the wavelength is:
The frequency of light entering a medium remains constant because:
questions.explanation: Continuity of the electromagnetic wave at the boundary enforces equal temporal frequency on both sides.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs represent complementary logic gates?
questions.explanation: XNOR outputs the complement of XOR for the same inputs, making them complementary.

questions.question: What is the effect of increasing forward bias on the width of the depletion region in a p-n junction?
questions.explanation: Forward bias reduces barrier potential, narrowing the depletion width.

questions.question: What happens to the depletion region under reverse bias?
questions.explanation: Reverse bias raises barrier potential, widening the depletion region and reducing current.

questions.question: Which type of semiconductor is obtained by doping pure germanium with antimony?
questions.explanation: Antimony is pentavalent, adding extra electrons to form n-type material.

questions.question: The intrinsic carrier concentration in a semiconductor:
options: Equals the difference between electron and hole concentrations
Equals the number of electrons in the conduction band in pure material
questions.explanation: Intrinsic carrier density equals the number of thermally generated electron-hole pairs in pure semiconductor.

questions.question: Which photon energy corresponds to 500 nm wavelength? (Use h c = 1240 eV nm)
Which statement about gamma rays is correct?
options: They are deflected by electric fields
They have longer wavelength than radio waves
They are electromagnetic radiation with very high frequency
questions.explanation: Gamma rays are high-frequency electromagnetic waves emitted during nuclear transitions.

questions.question: Which nuclear radiation has the greatest penetrating power?
questions.explanation: Gamma rays penetrate most due to lack of charge and high energy.

questions.question: Half-life of a radioactive sample is 10 days. What fraction remains undecayed after 30 days?
questions.explanation: Three half-lives elapse, so remaining fraction is (1/2)^3 = 1/8.

questions.question: The activity of a sample is proportional to:
questions.explanation: Activity A = λN, directly proportional to remaining nuclei.

questions.question: In nuclear fission, the mass defect appears as:
options: Kinetic energy of fission fragments and neutrons
questions.explanation: Released binding energy emerges mainly as kinetic energy of products and prompt gamma rays.

questions.question: A travelling wave has equation y = 0.02 cos(50x - 25t). What is its speed?
Which statement about harmonic waves is correct?
options: Amplitude depends on position and time
questions.explanation: For a given medium, wave speed (hence phase velocity) is determined by medium properties.

questions.question: For a standing wave formed on a string fixed at both ends, the distance between successive antinodes is:
questions.explanation: Antinodes are also separated by half the wavelength.

questions.question: If the surface tension of a liquid is increased, the capillary rise in a tube of fixed radius will:
questions.explanation: Capillary rise h = 2T cosθ/(ρgr); higher surface tension lifts the liquid further.

questions.question: The SI unit of surface tension is:
questions.explanation: Surface tension has dimensions of force per unit length (N m−1).

questions.question: The contact angle between water and clean glass is approximately:
questions.explanation: Water completely wets clean glass, giving a contact angle near zero.

questions.question: The unit of work function is:
questions.explanation: Work function is an energy per electron, commonly expressed in electron volts.

questions.question: The potential energy stored in a capacitor of capacitance C charged to voltage V is:
questions.explanation: Energy U = ½ CV^2.

questions.question: What is the energy density (energy per unit volume) in the electric field between capacitor plates with field strength E?
questions.explanation: Electric energy density in vacuum is u = ½ ε_0 E^2.

questions.question: For a harmonic oscillator, the displacement is x = A cos(ωt + φ). Which term represents the phase constant?
questions.explanation: φ is the phase constant fixing the initial state of oscillation.

questions.question: If two waves have a phase difference of π, they interfere to produce:
questions.explanation: Phase difference of π (180°) leads to complete destructive interference.

questions.question: The visibility of interference fringes decreases when:
options: Contrast between maxima and minima reduces
questions.explanation: Visibility V = (I_max - I_min)/(I_max + I_min); poor contrast reduces fringe visibility.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a requirement for sustained interference fringes?
questions.explanation: Large intensity mismatch reduces visibility; coherence, same frequency and constant phase difference are essential.

questions.question: The SI unit of pressure is:
questions.explanation: Pressure is measured in pascals (N m−2).

questions.question: Hydrostatic pressure at depth h in a liquid of density ρ is given by:
questions.explanation: Pascal's law gives p = p_0 + ρgh; gauge pressure is ρgh.

questions.question: Pascal's law states that pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted:
questions.explanation: The pressure change is equally transmitted throughout the fluid.

questions.question: Surface tension leads to which phenomenon in small liquid drops?
questions.explanation: Surface tension minimises surface area, producing nearly spherical drops.

questions.question: The rise of liquid in a capillary tube is greater when:
questions.explanation: Small contact angles (good wetting) maximise the cosine term in Jurin's law, increasing rise.

questions.question: Which factor causes damping of oscillations in a fluid?
questions.explanation: Viscous forces oppose motion, dissipating energy and damping oscillations.

questions.question: At resonance, the amplitude of a driven oscillator becomes large because:
questions.explanation: Maximum energy transfer occurs when the driving frequency matches the natural frequency.

questions.question: Which law defines the relation between emf in a loop and rate of change of magnetic flux?
questions.explanation: Faraday's law states emf = -dΦ/dt.

questions.question: Lenz's law ensures conservation of energy by stating that induced emf:
questions.explanation: Induced emf produces currents whose magnetic effects oppose the flux change, conserving energy.
